Authors: Lanzagorta M.; Jitrik O.; Uhlmann J.; Venegas S.
Author full names: Lanzagorta, Marco (6603979426); Jitrik, Oliverio (7801578912); Uhlmann, Jeffrey (7004498691); Venegas, Salvador (8957920100)
Title: Clutter attenuation using the Doppler effect in standoff electromagnetic quantum sensing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Ranken Institute, Mexico City, Mexico; University of Missouri-Columbia, MO, United States; Monterrey Institute of Technological, Mexico City, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Lanzagorta M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Jitrik O., Ranken Institute, Mexico City, Mexico; Uhlmann J., University of Missouri-Columbia, MO, United States; Venegas S., Monterrey Institute of Technological, Mexico City, Mexico
Abstract: In the context of traditional radar systems, the Doppler effect is crucial to detect and track moving targets in the presence of clutter. In the quantum radar context, however, most theoretical performance analyses to date have assumed static targets. In this paper we consider the Doppler effect at the single photon level. In particular, we describe how the Doppler effect produced by clutter and moving targets modifies the quantum distinguishability and the quantum radar error detection probability equations. Furthermore, we show that Doppler-based delayline cancelers can reduce the effects of clutter in the context of quantum radar, but only in the low-brightness regime. Thus, quantum radar may prove to be an important technology if the electronic battlefield requires stealthy tracking and detection of moving targets in the presence of clutter. © 2016 SPIE.

Authors: Jitrik O.; Lanzagorta M.; Uhlmann J.; Venegas-Andraca S.E.
Author full names: Jitrik, Oliverio (7801578912); Lanzagorta, Marco (6603979426); Uhlmann, Jeffrey (7004498691); Venegas-Andraca, Salvador E. (8957920100)
Title: Quantum geodesy
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Ranken Institute, Mexico City, Mexico; University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, United States; Tecnologico de Monterrey, Escuela de Ingenieria y Ciencias, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Jitrik O., Ranken Institute, Mexico City, Mexico; Lanzagorta M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States; Uhlmann J., University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, United States; Venegas-Andraca S.E., Tecnologico de Monterrey, Escuela de Ingenieria y Ciencias, Mexico
Abstract: The study of plate tectonic motion is important to generate theoretical models of the structure and dynamics of the Earth. In turn, understanding tectonic motion provides insight to develop sophisticated models that can be used for earthquake early warning systems and for nuclear forensics. Tectonic geodesy uses the position of a network of points on the surface of earth to determine the motion of tectonic plates and the deformation of the earths crust. GPS and interferometric synthetic aperture radar are commonly used techniques used in tectonic geodesy. In this paper we will describe the feasibility of interferometric synthetic aperture quantum radar and its theoretical performance for tectonic geodesy. © 2017 SPIE.

Authors: Dmitriev S.P.; Pazgalev A.S.; Petrenko M.V.; Vershovskii A.K.
Author full names: Dmitriev, S.P. (7102791516); Pazgalev, A.S. (6603519068); Petrenko, M.V. (23005991200); Vershovskii, A.K. (6602439339)
Title: All-Optical Quantum Sensor of the Magnetic Field Deflection
Affiliations: Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg, 194021, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dmitriev S.P., Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg, 194021, Russian Federation; Pazgalev A.S., Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg, 194021, Russian Federation; Petrenko M.V., Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg, 194021, Russian Federation; Vershovskii A.K., Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg, 194021, Russian Federation
Abstract: Abstract: A method is proposed for precise measurement of the deflection of the magnetic field vector. This method does not require the use of artificially created magnetic fields; a scheme of an all-optical quantum sensor based on this method has been experimentally tested. The proposed method does not involve the use of radiofrequency field, since it is based on measuring the polarization properties of an oriented paramagnetic medium and does not use the phenomenon of magnetic resonance. However, the inclusion of a resonant radiofrequency field into the proposed scheme allows the information about the angle of the magnetic field vector to be supplemented with information about its module. The proposed method maintains operability and provides the same angular sensitivity of the order of tens of angular milliseconds in a wide range of magnetic fields, from hundreds of nT to hundreds of µT and above. © 2019, Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.
Author Keywords: magnetic field measurement; optical quantum sensor; polarization rotation

Authors: Hegemann T.; Balasus J.; Trinh Q.V.; Herzog A.; Khanh T.Q.
Title: Using spectral sensors to determine photosynthetic photon flux density in daylight – A theoretical approach
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hegemann T., Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Balasus J., Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Trinh Q.V., Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Herzog A., Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany; Khanh T.Q., Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, Technical University of Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Precise determination of the photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD) is important for illumination in modern horticultural systems. This paper presents two methods to calculate the PPFD of daylight spectra using low cost optic sensors. The first method uses the spectral sensitivity functions of spectral sensors to recreate the quantum sensitivity curve of quantum sensors. Two sets of spectral sensitivity functions are compared. The second method calculates the PPFD based on the calculated correlated colour temperature and a spectral reconstruction using the CIE daylight model. It is demonstrated that all methods offer a useful estimation of the PPFD with correspondingly similar daylight spectra, but the supposedly simpler method, which is based on weighting of the individual channels, is more stable against deviations from the CIE daylight model. © The Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers 2022.

Authors: Yu Q.; Dong D.; Wang Y.; Petersen I.R.
Title: Capability comparison of quantum sensors of single or two qubits for a spin chain system
Affiliations: School of Engineering and Information Technology, University of New South Wales, Canberra, 2600, ACT, Australia; Research School of Electrical, Energy and Materials Engineering, Australian National University, Canberra, 2601, ACT, Australia; Centre for Quantum Dynamics, Griffith University, Brisbane, 4111, QLD, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Yu Q., School of Engineering and Information Technology, University of New South Wales, Canberra, 2600, ACT, Australia, Research School of Electrical, Energy and Materials Engineering, Australian National University, Canberra, 2601, ACT, Australia; Dong D., School of Engineering and Information Technology, University of New South Wales, Canberra, 2600, ACT, Australia; Wang Y., School of Engineering and Information Technology, University of New South Wales, Canberra, 2600, ACT, Australia, Centre for Quantum Dynamics, Griffith University, Brisbane, 4111, QLD, Australia; Petersen I.R., Research School of Electrical, Energy and Materials Engineering, Australian National University, Canberra, 2601, ACT, Australia
Abstract: Quantum sensing, utilizing quantum techniques to extract key information of a quantum (or classical) system, is a fundamental area in quantum science and technology. For quantum sensors, a basic capability is to uniquely infer unknown parameters in a system based on measurement data from the sensors. In this paper, we investigate the capability of a class of quantum sensors for a spin-12 chain system with unknown parameters. The sensors are composed of qubits which are coupled to the object system and can be initialized and measured. We consider the capability of the single- and two-qubit sensors and show that the capability of single-qubit quantum sensors can be enhanced by adding an extra qubit into the sensor under a certain initialization and measurement setting. Authors: Li L.; Hao L.; Gallop J.; Amad A.
Title: Density functional theory simulation of nitrogen-vacancy center in diamond as quantum sensor for neutrino mass detection
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Swansea University, Swansea, SA1 8EN, United Kingdom; Quantum Technologies Department, National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, TW11 0LW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Li L., College of Engineering, Swansea University, Swansea, SA1 8EN, United Kingdom; Hao L., Quantum Technologies Department, National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, TW11 0LW, United Kingdom; Gallop J., Quantum Technologies Department, National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, TW11 0LW, United Kingdom; Amad A., College of Engineering, Swansea University, Swansea, SA1 8EN, United Kingdom
Abstract: Nitrogen-vacancy (NV) pair in diamond has been widely investigated due to its profound quantum properties even at relatively higher temperature compared with those materials having to satisfy strict cryogenic conditions to display quantum states. Spin properties of NV center in diamond can be tuned by external electromagnetic radiations, which leads to its application in detecting microwave signals. Here in this work, density functional theory (DFT) method has been used to analyze electronic properties of diamond with NV centers with the aim of utilizing it for detecting very weak microwave radiations from electron cryotron radiations, to ultimately determine neutrino mass.  © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.

Title: An autonomous mobile robot based on quantum algorithm
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Automation, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui 230027, China

Abstract: In this paper, we design a novel autonomous mobile robot which uses quantum sensors to detect faint signals and fulfills some learning tasks using quantum reinforcement learning (QRL) algorithms. In this robot, a multi-sensor system is designed with SQUID sensor and quantum Hall sensor, where quantum sensors coexist with traditional sensors. A novel QRL algorithm is applied and a simple simulation example demonstrates its validity. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2005.

Title: Quantum Information Science, Sensing, and Computation XII
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 10 papers. The topics discussed include: quantum fisher information matrix of a single qutrit in Xi or cascade configuration; a hybrid quantum enabled RBM advantage: convolutional autoencoders for quantum image compression and generative learning; GaN laser diodes for quantum sensors and optical atomic clocks; wavefront design for improved performance by entangled systems; a semi-quantum extended B92 protocol and its analysis; approximate graph spectral decomposition with the variational quantum eigensolver; quantum central limit theorem and statistical hypothesis testing in discrete quantum walk; and objective function maximization by machine learning for gate-model quantum computers.

Authors: Alcântara E.
Author full names: Alcântara, Enner (23491677700)
Title: Remote sensing: Techniques, applications and technologies
Source title: Remote Sensing: Techniques, Applications and Technologies
Affiliations: Sao Paulo State University (UNESP), Department of Cartography - Presidente Prudente, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Alcântara E., Sao Paulo State University (UNESP), Department of Cartography - Presidente Prudente, Brazil
Abstract: In this book, the authors present current research in the study of the techniques, applications and technologies of remote sensing. Topics discussed include the techniques used to investigate the surface dynamics of coastal areas using radar remote sensing; technologies to understand crop status from different sensors including multispectral camera, spectrometer, laser range finder and light quantum sensors; hydrological modeling, flood forecasting, water conservation and efficiency in irrigation; the horizontal transport and dispersion in large hydroelectric reservoirs through the use of satellite tracked drifters; imaging cameras as an intelligent device for extracting relative attitude information needed for attitude control; and techniques to study the urban growth over time, combining unsupervised, supervised classifications and the spectral mixture analysis. © 2013 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
Abbreviated Source Title: Remote Sensing: Tech., Appl. and Technol.

Authors: Finch D.A.; Bailey W.G.; McArthur L.J.B.; Nasitwitwi M.
Title: Photosynthetically active radiation in Zambia
Source title: 26th Conference on Agricultural and Forest Meteorology
Affiliations: Queen's University, Kingston, Ont., Canada; Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada; Meteorological Service of Canada, Downsview, Ont., Canada; Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, Ont. K7L 3N6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Finch D.A., Queen's University, Kingston, Ont., Canada, Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, Ont. K7L 3N6, Canada; Bailey W.G., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada; McArthur L.J.B., Meteorological Service of Canada, Downsview, Ont., Canada; Nasitwitwi M., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada
Abstract: The temporal variation in K↓ and photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) at Lusaka, Zambia was presented. An Eppley Precision Spectral Pyranometer (PSP) was used to measure K↓ and a LICOR Li-190 quantum sensor was used to measure PAR (photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD)). The mean daily PAR/K↓ ratio decreased during the hot-dry season and increased in the warm-wet season. The results show that the variation was due to trends in cloudiness and the associated atmospheric moisture associated with the movement of the Haadley cell circulation system.

Authors: Christ M.; Kassner A.; Smol R.; Bawamia A.; Heine H.; Herr W.; Peters A.; Wurz M.C.; Rasel E.M.; Wicht A.; Krutzik M.
Author full names: Christ, Marc (57200137962); Kassner, Alexander (57209410009); Smol, Robert (57193407737); Bawamia, Ahmad (26641065800); Heine, Hendrik (57204610210); Herr, Waldemar (24766237700); Peters, Achim (7402105599); Wurz, Marc Christopher (8624052500); Rasel, Ernst Maria (23981054000); Wicht, Andreas (6603956883); Krutzik, Markus (36155460100)
Title: Integrated atomic quantum technologies in demanding environments: development and qualification of miniaturized optical setups and integration technologies for UHV and space operation

Abstract: Employing quantum sensors in field or in space implies demanding requirements on the used components and integration technologies. Within our work on compact atomic sensors, we develop miniaturized, ultra-stable optical setups for optical cooling and trapping of cold atomic gases on atom chips. Besides challenging demands on alignment precision and thermo-mechanical durability, we specifically address ultra-high vacuum (UHV) compatibility of our adhesive integration technology and the assembled optical components. A prototype of an UHV-compatible, crossed beam optical dipole trap at 1064 nm for application within a cold rubidium atomic quantum sensor currently in development at the Joint Lab Integrated Quantum Sensors at Ferdinand-Braun-Institut, Leibniz-Institut für Höchstfrequenztechnik is described. We describe the design and first qualification efforts on adhesive micro-integration technologies. These tests are conducted in application-relevant geometries and material combinations common for micro-integrated optical setups. Adhesive aging will be investigated by thermal cycling and radiation exposure. For vacuum compatibility testing, a versatile UHV testing system for samples up to 65×65mm2 footprint is currently being set up, enabling residual gas analysis, temperature cycling up to 200∘C and measurement of total gas rates down to expected 5×10-10mbarl/s at a base pressure of 10-11mbar, exceeding the common ASTM E595 test. © 2019, CEAS.

Authors: Bray C.E.; Hiller L.J.; Leach K.G.; Friedrich S.
Title: Monte Carlo Simulations of Superconducting Tunnel Junction Quantum Sensors for the BeEST Experiment
Affiliations: Colorado School of Mines, Golden, 80401, CO, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bray C.E., Colorado School of Mines, Golden, 80401, CO, United States; Hiller L.J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Leach K.G., Colorado School of Mines, Golden, 80401, CO, United States; Friedrich S., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States
Abstract: Superconducting Tunnel Junctions (STJs) are used as high-resolution quantum sensors to search for evidence of sterile neutrinos in the electron capture decay of 7Be. We are developing spatially resolved Monte Carlo simulations of the energy relaxation in superconductors to understand electron escape after the 7Be decay and distinguish details in the STJ response function from a possible sterile neutrino signal. Simulations of the charge generation and the Fano factor for different materials agree with the literature values. Initial simulations of the escape tail are consistent with observations and contain fine structure in the line shape. The line shape will be refined as better experimental data become available. © 2022, The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.

Authors: Kawakata T.; Yajima M.; Moriya T.
Author full names: Kawakata, Toshikazu (6507486656); Yajima, Masaharu (7102573433); Moriya, Takashi (57192734966)
Title: On Characteristics of Two Types of Tube Quantum Sensors
Affiliations: Division of Agrometeorology, National Institute of Agro Environmental Sciences, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Koito Industries, LTD, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawakata T., Division of Agrometeorology, National Institute of Agro Environmental Sciences, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yajima M., Division of Agrometeorology, National Institute of Agro Environmental Sciences, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Moriya T., Koito Industries, LTD, Minato-ku, Tokyo 108, Japan
Abstract: We made two types of tube light sensors, one is a continuous type, and the other is a discrete type. These sensors enable us to measure a mean photon flux density in a crop canopy, so it is possible to predict the growth and the yield of the crop. In this study, we introduced these tube light sensors, and compared distribution of the output voltage. The Variation of the continuous type was much smaller than that of the discrete type. We calculated the Standard deviation and the coefficient of Variation of the output voltage, when some light Spots shone on these sensors randomly. These values of the continuous type were about from one eighth to one ninth times as large as those of the discrete type. We indicated that the continuous type was much stable. © 1992, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Crop canopy; Instrument; Prediction; Tube light sensor

Authors: Ehrenberg A.; Bringewatt J.; Gorshkov A.V.
Author full names: Ehrenberg, Adam (57211784942); Bringewatt, Jacob (57200722630); Gorshkov, Alexey V. (16052665500)
Title: Minimum-entanglement protocols for function estimation
Affiliations: Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States; Joint Quantum Institute, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrenberg A., Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States, Joint Quantum Institute, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States; Bringewatt J., Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States, Joint Quantum Institute, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States; Gorshkov A.V., Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States, Joint Quantum Institute, NIST, University of Maryland, College Park, 20742, MD, United States
Abstract: We derive a family of optimal protocols, in the sense of saturating the quantum Cramér-Rao bound, for measuring a linear combination of d field amplitudes with quantum sensor networks, a key subprotocol of general quantum sensor network applications. We demonstrate how to select different protocols from this family under various constraints. Focusing primarily on entanglement-based constraints, we prove the surprising result that highly entangled states are not necessary to achieve optimality in many cases. Specifically, we prove necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of optimal protocols using at most k-partite entanglement. We prove that the protocols which satisfy these conditions use the minimum amount of entanglement possible, even when given access to arbitrary controls and ancillas. Our protocols require some amount of time-dependent control, and we show that a related class of time-independent protocols fail to achieve optimal scaling for generic functions.  © 2023 authors. Published by the American Physical Society. Published by the American Physical Society under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Further distribution of this work must maintain attribution to the author(s) and the published article's title, journal citation, and DOI.

Title: Quantum Technologies and Quantum Information Science V
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 7 papers. The topics discussed include: quantum implementation of the shor-code on multiple simulator platforms; the Hilbert-Schmidt inner product: quantum illumination and beyond; stratospheric QKD: feasibility analysis and free-space optics system concept; GaN laser diodes for quantum sensors and optical atomic clocks; object tracking and identification by quantum radar; towards hyperentangled time-bin and polarization superdense teleportation in space; and how much value does adaptive optics add to a satellite QKD uplink?.

Title: Emerging Imaging and Sensing Technologies for Security and Defence V; and Advanced Manufacturing Technologies for Micro- and Nanosystems in Security and Defence III
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 23 papers. The topics discussed include: advances in GaN laser diodes for quantum sensors and optical atomic clocks; including the vacuum in the post-selected model of quantum illumination; turbulence mitigation in neuromorphic camera imagery; performance assessment of reconstruction algorithms for compressed sensing threat detection applications; imaging from temporal data via spiking convolutional neural networks; photon counting 3D imaging from multiple positions; underwater time-of-flight depth imaging using an asynchronous linear single photon avalanche diode detector array; investigation of some limitations of non-line-of-sight scene reconstruction; neuromorphic technologies for defense and security; stress induced birefringence of glass-to-metal bonded components; and voltammetry as a rapid screening method for NPS identification.

Title: Compact and portable quantum sensor module using diamond NV centers

Abstract: We developed a compact and portable measuring instrument using diamond NV centers that operates on the USB 3.0 power supply of a laptop computer. Its portability is achieved by the low power consumption of the optics, realized by the diamond corner cube that enhanced the current of the photodiode to 2.1 times higher than that of the planar diamond, and that of the microwave source, reduced by 20 dB, which was realized by a microwave resonator using a λ/4 open stub that strongly magnetically drives the NV center. These results contribute to the social implementation of diamond sensors. © 2023 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Title: Infrared electro-optical detector to rescue humans
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Inst. Nac. de Astrofis. Optica/E., C.P. 72000, Puebla, Pue., Apdo. Postal 51 y 217, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Ysi-Zarco P., Inst. Nac. de Astrofis. Optica/E., C.P. 72000, Puebla, Pue., Apdo. Postal 51 y 217, Mexico; Ramos J.C., Inst. Nac. de Astrofis. Optica/E., C.P. 72000, Puebla, Pue., Apdo. Postal 51 y 217, Mexico; Gordiano-Alvarado G., Inst. Nac. de Astrofis. Optica/E., C.P. 72000, Puebla, Pue., Apdo. Postal 51 y 217, Mexico
Abstract: We designed and built an electro-optical sensor to detect human bodies. The aim of this paper is to describe a device to make easier the localization of lost people in natural disasters or in dangerous environments. The detection is realized in base of the infrared radiation emitted by the human body. We employ point commercial pyloric quantum sensors, the electronic assembly integrates the captured infrared energy by using low noise chip. The optical device include a Cassegrain antenna, a diffraction grating which besides to choose in automatic way the correct wavelength emitted by the human body, it is useful as optical filter.

Authors: Borisenok S.
Author full names: Borisenok, Sergey (14055402800)
Title: Control over performance of qubit-based sensors
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Abdullah Gül University, Turkey; Feza Gürsey Center for Physics and Mathematics, Boğaziçi University, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Borisenok S., Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Abdullah Gül University, Turkey, Feza Gürsey Center for Physics and Mathematics, Boğaziçi University, Turkey
Abstract: The extreme sensitivity of quantum systems towards the external perturbations and in the same time their ability to be strongly coupled to the measured target field makes them to be stable under the environmental noise. A high quality quantum sensor can be engineered even on the platform of a single trapped qubit. There is a variety of optimal and sub-optimal algorithms for effective control over the quantum system states. Here we discuss the opportunity to improve the efficiency of the external field quantum sensor based on a single qubit via its feedback tracking. © 2018, Institute for Problems in Mechanical Engineering, Russian Academy of Sciences. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Feedback tracking algorithms; Quantum fisher information; Quantum sensors

Authors: Ellison R.M.; Bendis B.
Author full names: Ellison, Robert M. (22733723600); Bendis, Brian (6507532958)
Title: Keeping constant watch on harmful algal blooms
Affiliations: Global Market/Business Development; YSI Inc., Yellow Springs, OH, United States; AMJ Environmental, St. Petersburg, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ellison R.M., Global Market/Business Development, YSI Inc., Yellow Springs, OH, United States; Bendis B., AMJ Environmental, St. Petersburg, FL, United States
Abstract: Pontoon-mounted MARVIN (MERHAB [Monitoring and Event Response for Harmful Algal Blooms (HAB)] Autonomous Research Vessel In-Situ) plays an increasingly important role for scientists and researchers from the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission's Fish and Wildlife Research Institute (FWRI) for keeping a constant watch on harmful algal blooms (HAB). The real-time monitoring platform, which operate unattended and require relatively less maintenance, can collect valuable data from extremely high temporal resolution. It is equipped with a Vaisala WXT510 weather transmitter on a meteorological tower for collecting data on wind direction and speed, barometric pressure, air temperature, relative humidity, and rainfall. It also incorporates a YSI 6600EDS multiparameter sonde, a YSI 9600 nitrate monitor with a pre-filter, and LI-COR (Lincoln, Nebraska) quantum sensors. The data collected by the cost effective autonomous sampling MARVIN platform also are extremely accurate, which help researchers to track storm events, lake releases, seasonal patterns, and diurnal cycles.
Index Keywords: Algae; Atmospheric humidity; Fish; Pressure effects; Rain; Real time systems; algae; air temperature; algal bloom; environmental monitoring; rainfall; relative humidity; sensor; wind direction; wind velocity

Authors: Turn S.Q.; Walker P.N.
Title: DESIGN AND OPERATION OF A TEST FACILITY FOR DETERMINING PHOTOSYNTHETIC PHOTON FLUX DENSITY DISTRIBUTION OF LUMINAIRES FOR GREENHOUSES.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Turn S.Q., Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA; Walker P.N., Pennsylvania State Univ, University, Park, PA, USA, Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, PA, USA
Abstract: A facility was designed and constructed for testing luminaires which are used for supplemental greenhouse lighting, to determine their photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD) distribution patterns. In the facility, a microcomputer controls the movement of a luminaire and a quantum sensor, and collects and records data from the sensor. To demonstrate the use of this facility, a single luminaire was tested at heights of 1. 5 and 2. 0 m. Test data were analyzed and contour plots of PPFD were produced. PPFD distributions were then calculated for 2. 0 m and 3. 0 m luminaire spacing grids with a luminaire height of 1. 5 m. The uniformity coefficient was determined and a contour plot of PPFD was made of a typical grid sector for each spacing. The 2. 0 m spacing had an average PPFD of 90. 5 mu mol s** minus **1 m** minus **2 and a uniformity coefficient of 0. 84; whereas for the 3. 0 m spacing, these values were 40. 2 and 0. 75 respectively.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC LIGHTING - Photosynthesis; GREENHOUSES - Lighting; PHOTONS - Measurements; LUMINAIRES; PHOTON FLUX DENSITY DISTRIBUTION; LIGHTING FIXTURES

Abstract: The negatively charged NV center in diamond pillars is one of the most prominent quantum sensors. However, the sensitivity is limited by the poor photon extraction efficiency. The goal of our work is to improve the photon collection efficiency so as to achieve new generation diamond nanoprobes with higher sensitivity. © 2019 OSA - The Optical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Vogtschaller J.; Wise R.
Author full names: Vogtschaller, Jeff (6504228573); Wise, Robert (7402491133)
Title: Simple light guide for measuring irradiance in an aqueous oxygen electrode chamber
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Wisconsin Madison, 430 Lincoln Dr., WI, USA, United States; Department of Biology, University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, 800 Algoma Blvd, WI, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vogtschaller J., Department of Botany, University of Wisconsin Madison, 430 Lincoln Dr., WI, USA, United States; Wise R., Department of Biology, University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, 800 Algoma Blvd, WI, USA, United States
Abstract: The light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis are often measured with Clark-type oxygen electrodes yet the irradiance level inside aqueous oxygen electrode reaction vessels is seldom reported due to the difficulty of measuring light inside a small volume chamber. We describe a simple light guide terminating in a 90° prism that can be inserted into a reaction vessel. Incoming irradiation is directed to a commercially available quantum sensor positioned at the other end of the light guide. Both materials for and construction of the device are inexpensive.
Author Keywords: Light measurement; Oxygen electrode; Photosynthesis

Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 20 papers. The topics discussed include: simulation and signal processing of through wall UWB radar for human being's periodic motions detection; wideband radar micro-Doppler applications; UWB micro-Doppler radar for human gait analysis using joint range-time-frequency representation; a measurement approach based on micro-Doppler maps for signature and motion analysis; an image-based approach for classification of human micro-Doppler radar signatures; micro-Doppler radar classification of human motions under various training scenarios; multi-aspect angle classification of human radar signatures; signal and image processing algorithm performance in a virtual and elastic computing environment; amplification of radar and lidar signatures using quantum sensors; Raman Albedo and deep-UV resonance Raman signatures of explosives; and infrared enhanced detection for laser imaging and biometrics.
Sponsors: The Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers (SPIE)

Authors: Riou I.; Chichet L.; Edwards I.; Kiss-Toth M.; Reilly J.; Renshaw R.
Author full names: Riou, Isabelle (57190985988); Chichet, Laure (56845795600); Edwards, Ian (57838057000); Kiss-Toth, Marton (57413152500); Reilly, James (57101384200); Renshaw, Ryan (58385823200)
Title: Embedded cold atom accelerometer for atmospheric drag measurement
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Riou I., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom; Chichet L., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom; Edwards I., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom; Kiss-Toth M., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom; Reilly J., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom; Renshaw R., Teledyne e2v, 106 Waterhouse Lane, Chelmsford, CM1 2QU, United Kingdom
Abstract: Below 600 km, drag is the largest source of uncertainty for satellite and debris orbit prediction. With an increasing number of satellites in low-Earth orbit, accurate observations of the atmospheric mass density are required to improve models of the thermosphere with applications in satellite lifetime predictions, collision risk assessment and avoidance. We are developing a compact cold atom accelerometer for atmospheric density missions, to be launched in mid to late 2020s. These quantum sensors are based on atom interferometry. A cold atom sample is generated using the combination of an atom-chip and resonant laser beams. The cold atom cloud is then diffracted using a set of three laser pulses, generating a matter-wave interferometer. The phase-shift at the output of the interferometer is proportional to the acceleration of the free falling atoms with respect to the satellite, which is converted to density observations. Teledyne e2v is producing a space suitable accelerometer physics package that can be embedded in small satellites such as a 16U cubesat or a SkimSat. It includes an atom-chip for producing magnetic fields local to the atoms in vacuum developed by RAL Space. It will address some of the engineering challenges associated with the launch and the required low SWAP and will be integrated into a breadboard system capable of acceleration measurement in order to test interferometry schemes suitable for measurements in micro-gravity. Atmospheric drag measurement can be the world's first cold atom Earth observation mission and be a pathfinder for a future large-scale cold atom gravity mission. © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.

Title: Room temperature magnetic field learning with optically readout single NV-centers
Affiliations: Quantum Engineering Technology Labs, University of Bristol, Bristol, BS8 1FD, United Kingdom; Institute of Quantum Optics, Ulm University, Ulm, 89081, Germany; Quantum Architectures and Computation Group, Microsoft Research, Redmond, 98052, WA, United States

Abstract: We propose and test a Magnetic Field Learning (MFL) protocol for high-resolution, high dynamic range and high-sensitivity magnetometry with a single NV-center electron spin. Our approach leverages recent proposals that analyze the benefits of adopting classical machine learning to post-process quantum data in quantum sensing protocols [1]. MFL was tested at room-temperature using a setup detecting state-dependent fluorescence via confocal microscopy, and a microwave controlled NV defect in bulk diamond as a sensor [2]. This setup senses the intensity of a magnetic field B in the proximity of the quantum sensor via Ramsey interferometry [3]. In our protocol, the Ramsey precession time τi is adaptively chosen at each step via an efficient particle guess heuristic [1]. © 2019 IEEE
Index Keywords: Magnetic moments; Magnetometers; Magnetometry; Microwave sensors; Room temperature; Electron spins; High dynamic range; High resolution; High sensitivity; Learning protocols; Machine-learning; Magnetic-field; NV center; Post process; Quantum data; Magnetic fields

Authors: Jaubert Jean M.; Chisholm John R.M.; Marchioretti Manuel; Priouzeau Fabrice
Author full names: Jaubert, Jean M. (55947652600); Chisholm, John R.M. (7102693151); Marchioretti, Manuel (7801547729); Priouzeau, Fabrice (7801419262)
Title: Submersible respirometer designed to measure the metabolism of benthic marine plants and invertebrates
Affiliations: Cent Scientifique de Monaco, Monaco
Authors with affiliations: Jaubert Jean M., Cent Scientifique de Monaco, Monaco; Chisholm John R.M., Cent Scientifique de Monaco, Monaco; Marchioretti Manuel, Cent Scientifique de Monaco, Monaco; Priouzeau Fabrice, Cent Scientifique de Monaco, Monaco
Abstract: The respirometer included: a data-logger (Li-1000, Li-Cor), secured within a pressure-resistant, waterproof, acrylic housing; different sets of transparent incubation chambers fitted within polarographic O2 electrodes, containing built-in temperature sensors; and a spherical (4p) quantum sensor. Inlet and outlet teflon ball valves were fitted to the base of each incubation chamber and connected by Tygon hose to an external centrifugal pump, which flushed the chambers at regular intervals with fresh seawater. Incubations lasted a total of 24 h. The respirometer was used to investigate the primary production, at different depths, by the green alga Caulerpa taxifolia in the northern Mediterranean and by ≪micro-colonies≫ of the reef-building coral Stylophora pistillata in the northern Red Sea. These investigations indicated: (a) that C. taxifolia may satisfy a significant proportion of its basal metabolic requirement at depths greater than 25-30 m near Monaco by uptake of organic carbon from substrata via its subterranean rhizoids; and (b) that S. pistillata comprises 3 different depth (light) adapted strains in the Gulf of Aqaba.
Index Keywords: Algebra; Electrodes; Marine biology; Metabolism; Plastic parts; Pumps; Quantum electronics; Reefs; Sensors; Submersible respirometers; Underwater equipment

Authors: Zhang X.; Zhang F.; Li M.; Zhang Z.; Liu W.
Title: Design and applications of multichannel photosynthetic photon flux density sensor for artificial lighting
Affiliations: University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang X., University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China; Zhang F., University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China; Li M., University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China; Zhang Z., University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China; Liu W., University of Science and Technology of China, School of Physical Sciences, Hefei, China
Abstract: The measurement of plant growth's light environment is the basis of urban agriculture, such as light-emitting diode plant factories. The photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD) sensors, which measure the photon flux density of radiation in the spectral interval from 400 to 700 nm, cannot measure the spectral components, including the photon flux density of red light band and the photon flux density of blue light band, the light in these two bands are widely used in plant lighting. Facility agriculture, especially plant factories with artificial lighting, needs these data and their ratios by far, so a type of multichannel PPFD sensor is designed to solve these problems. First, we expound the design principle, circuit, and structure of the sensor, and calibrate the unregulated sensors by a standard PPFD sensor (PQS-1, Holland) under the calibration device constructed by controller based on DMX512 protocol. The test results show that the sensor's average variance is 0.9956, which approximates the ideal linear response value 1. Meanwhile, we make a black opaque soft plastic anticrosslight sleeve using three-dimensional printing to solve the problem of crosslight on the sidewall of the filter, which let the crosslight error coefficient of the red and blue channels reduced by an order of magnitude and approached 0. Finally, we designed a set of light environment control systems, which can autocontrol the PPFD and light quality ratios, and a set of supplemental lighting systems, which can control the daily light integral, based on the sensors. © 2019 Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers (SPIE).
Author Keywords: calibration; light environment control; multichannel; photosynthetic photon flux density sensor; plant factory

Author full names: Frazier, Gary (7006712706); McCarley, Paul (6603372916)
Title: Quantum imager and processor for guided interceptor applications
Source title: 2nd AIAA SDIO Annual Interceptor Technology Conference, 1993
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Incorporated, Dallas, TX, United States; Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frazier G., Texas Instruments Incorporated, Dallas, TX, United States; McCarley P., Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate, Eglin AFB, FL, United States
Abstract: Full integration of large sensor and processor arrays will eventually require the development of logic devices and circuits that can be scaled down to nanometer geometries. This level of integration can only be obtained by a revolutionary approach to avoiding the scaling limits of conventional integrated circuits (ICs). Nanoelectronics is an emerging IC technology that will exploit quantum electronic effects in nanometer-sized heterojunction devices to enable single chip image pnxcssing systems consisting of millions of sensor-processor elements. In a quantum image processor, each sensor will be integrated with a high performance signal processor to provide a chip-Jevel throughput that approaches 1 million TeraOps. litis paper discusses the thermodynamic and other physical limits to developing monolithic, quantum sensor processors and summarizes the processor architecture, device and circuit concepts that are in development. © 1993 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Wills Physics Laboratory, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Bristol, BS8 1FD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Quantum photonic technology encodes information within single photons, and the entanglement between them. Quantum sensors accumulate information about their environment in single photons; quantum-secured communications distribute secret quantum key between parties on photons; and optical quantum computers wield huge entangled states of photons to arrive at their answers. For all these applications, photon loss is catastrophic. © 2019 IEEE

Authors: Leon-Salas W.D.; Rajendran J.; Vizcardo M.A.; Postigo-Malaga M.
Author full names: Leon-Salas, Walter D. (16175379800); Rajendran, Jegan (57225047990); Vizcardo, Miguel A. (6503955900); Postigo-Malaga, Mauricio (57193608600)
Title: Measuring photosynthetically active radiation with a multi-channel integrated spectral sensor
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: School of Engineering Technology, Purdue University, Indiana, United States; Universidad Nacional de San Agustin, Arequipa, Peru
Authors with affiliations: Leon-Salas W.D., School of Engineering Technology, Purdue University, Indiana, United States; Rajendran J., School of Engineering Technology, Purdue University, Indiana, United States; Vizcardo M.A., Universidad Nacional de San Agustin, Arequipa, Peru; Postigo-Malaga M., Universidad Nacional de San Agustin, Arequipa, Peru
Abstract: This paper presents a photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) sensor based on an 18-band spectral sensor chipset with integrated optical filters. PAR sensors are an important tool for farmers and the proposed solution offers a path to low-cost PAR sensors. A technique for correcting the optical spectral leakage in the spectral sensor chipset is proposed and is applied to measurements collected indoors and outdoors. Tests results show that the proposed sensor and leakage-correction technique outperform lab-grade commercially-available PAR sensors. © 2021 IEEE
Index Keywords: Chipset; Correction techniques; Integrated optical filters; Low costs; Multi channel; Photosynthetically active radiation; Spectral leakage; Spectral sensors; Networks (circuits)

Authors: Lapyga I.
Title: Application of light sensors amplifier and wireless networking sensor for ambient light data to the android platform
Source title: International Journal of Recent Technology and Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Ecology, National M.P. Dragomanov pedagogical university, Kyiv, 01601, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Lapyga I., Department of Ecology, National M.P. Dragomanov pedagogical university, Kyiv, 01601, Ukraine
Abstract: Modern technologies of growing different plants types in greenhouses envisage automated systems use for monitoring climatic parameters, on which the ripening of fruits and yields depend. At the development and application of such automated systems, the focus is on measuring the accuracy of temperature and humidity soil, whereas to determine the level of illumination used sensors, that measure the total illumination or Photosynthetic Active Radiation (400-700 nm) with error up to 20%. Under conditions of insufficient photon flux density, even at the optimal moisture level and temperature in the greenhouse, fruiting and crop yields may not achieve high performance. This article proposes a greenhouse lighting control system in which the LI-200R Pyranometer and LI-190R-BL Quantum Sensor measure not only total illumination from the wavelength of 400–1000 nm, but also PPFD from a wavelength of 400–700 nm. Light Sensor Amplifier provides an increase in the source signal of the measuring sensors and reduces their measurement error to 1%. The applied SMART Connectivity Platform ESP8266 Version ESP 07 is more robust to interference and ensures the transfer of measured data to the server. Created software application for smartphones with Android OS, ensures remote user access to the database via the Internet for remote control and analysis of climatic indicators in the greenhouse. The proposed illumination control system in the greenhouse contributes to the improvement of precision farming. © BEIESP.
Author Keywords: Greenhouse; Internet of Things; Light Sensor Amplifier; Quantum Light Sensor
Funding Details: National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, NASU

Title: Enhanced quantum sensing with nitrogen-vacancy centers in nanodiamonds using all-optical charge control

Abstract: We demonstrate an all-optical protocol for ensemble charge readout and spin-to-charge conversion of nitrogen-vacancy centers in room-temperature nanodiamonds. This technique provides drastic improvements for electrochemical sensing and an order-of-magnitude speedup for spin-based quantum sensors. © OSA 2017.

Authors: Ertmer W.; Rasel E.M.
Title: Towards Atomic Quantum Sensors in Microgravity
Affiliations: Institut für Quantenoptik (IQ), Leibniz-Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ertmer W., Institut für Quantenoptik (IQ), Leibniz-Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Germany; Rasel E.M., Institut für Quantenoptik (IQ), Leibniz-Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Welfengarten 1, Germany
Abstract: In this article we present actual projects concerning high resolution measurements developed for future space missions based on ultracold atoms. This work involves the realization of a Bose Einstein Condensate in microgravitational environment and of an inertial atomic quantum sensor. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Funding Details: Deutsche Zentrum fur Luft und Raumfahrt, (DLR 50 WM 0346)
Funding Texts: various aspects of ultra-cold gases in microgravity like adiabatic release, extended coherent evolution and features of atom lasers. The project is supported by the Deutsche Zentrum fur Luft und Raumfahrt (DLR, project number DLR 50 WM 0346) [8]. A compact differential interferometer is the Cold Atom Sagnac Interferometer (CASI). In this experiment we use ultracold 87Rb atoms in a differential measurement scheme for extremely precise sensing of rotations and accelerations. As a longterm goal the combination of coherent atomic sources with high resolution atom interferometry could lead to even better accuracies, especially when profiting from low-noise environments like microgravity. This could give new insights in questions of fundamental physics, relativistic effects or gravitation. In this paper we present in detail these two projects developed for future space missions.

Authors: Akitsu T.; Nasahara K.N.; Hirose Y.; Ijima O.; Kume A.
Author full names: Akitsu, Tomoko (56662866500); Nasahara, Kenlo Nishida (24178270500); Hirose, Yasuo (56662732100); Ijima, Osamu (6506659694); Kume, Atsushi (7005574346)
Title: Quantum sensors for accurate and stable long-term photosynthetically active radiation observations
Affiliations: Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, 1-1-1 Tennodai, Tsukuba, 305-8572, Japan; Center for Global Environmental Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies, 16-2 Onogawa, Tsukuba, 305-8506, Japan; Aerological Observatory, Japan Meteorological Agency, 1-2 Nagamine, Tsukuba, 305-0052, Japan; Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akitsu T., Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, 1-1-1 Tennodai, Tsukuba, 305-8572, Japan; Nasahara K.N., Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Tsukuba, 1-1-1 Tennodai, Tsukuba, 305-8572, Japan; Hirose Y., Center for Global Environmental Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies, 16-2 Onogawa, Tsukuba, 305-8506, Japan; Ijima O., Aerological Observatory, Japan Meteorological Agency, 1-2 Nagamine, Tsukuba, 305-0052, Japan; Kume A., Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka, 812-8581, Japan
Abstract: Long-term accurate data of photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) are needed because PAR is one of the standard environmental statistics needed to evaluate plant photosynthesis. Therefore, PAR observation sites are globally distributed, particularly in flux observation sites. Quantum sensors have been used for half a century to observe PAR; however, their accuracy is still uncertain. This study evaluates the accuracies of nine quantum sensor products by examining their spectral and cosine responses. On the basis of these data as well as reference spectrum data provided by our standard spectrometric measurement, we performed the following analyses: (1) a simulation of errors caused by the sensors’ non-ideal spectral response in three types of radiation inputs (open sky, forest canopy transmission, and forest canopy reflection), (2) a simulation of the errors caused by a complex combination of the sensors’ non-ideal spectral and cosine responses in three diurnal variation types of incident radiation (clear sky, partial clouds, and an overcast sky), and (3) an observation of the sensors’ long-term sensitivity degradation outdoors. Based on the results, we recommend two quantum sensors with minimal errors, LI-COR LI-190 encased in a weather-proof external housing with a glass dome and PREDE PAR-02D. The findings of this study contribute in establishing a long-term PAR observation protocol and should become a basis for quality checks and controls of PAR observation values that have previously been obtained worldwide. © 2017 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Cosine error; Long-term sensitivity degradation; Quantum sensor; Reference standard; Spectral error; Spectral radiation

Authors: Shimazoe K.; Tomita H.; Watts D.; Moskal P.; Kagawa A.; Thirolf P.G.; Budker D.; Levin C.S.
Title: Quantum Sensing for Biomedical Applications
Source title: 2021 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium and Medical Imaging Conference Record, NSS/MIC 2021 and 28th International Symposium on Room-Temperature Semiconductor Detectors, RTSD 2022
Affiliations: University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Nagoya University, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan; University of York, York, YO10 5DD, United Kingdom; Jagiellonian University, Institute of Physics, Krakow, Poland; Osaka University, Osaka, Japan; Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Garching, D-85748, Germany; Johannes Gutenberg University, Helmholtz Institute, Mainz, Germany; University of California, Berkeley, United States; Stanford University, 94305, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shimazoe K., University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; Tomita H., Nagoya University, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan; Watts D., University of York, York, YO10 5DD, United Kingdom; Moskal P., Jagiellonian University, Institute of Physics, Krakow, Poland; Kagawa A., Osaka University, Osaka, Japan; Thirolf P.G., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Garching, D-85748, Germany; Budker D., Johannes Gutenberg University, Helmholtz Institute, Mainz, Germany, University of California, Berkeley, United States; Levin C.S., Stanford University, 94305, CA, United States
Abstract: Quantum technology, such as the quantum computers, has attracted significant attention in recent years. In nuclear medicine, powerful and highly sensitive molecular imaging modalities such as PET (Positron Emission Tomography), SPECT (Single Photon Emission CT) and MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) provide accurate morphological and functional information. Exploiting certain aspects of quantum mechanics may bring further improvements in sensitivity, spatial resolution and enable novel capabilities in the field of biomedical imaging and sensing. In this workshop, the possibilities of biomedical applications inspired by quantum technology were discussed. The following exciting topics were covered: quantum entanglement in PET, dynamic nuclear polarization toward more sensitive MRI, quantum sensors based on the 229mTh nuclear clock, plans of an advanced high-energy gamma-ray source at CERN, laser-assisted radiation detection, solid-state quantum sensors such as those based on nitrogen vacancy centers in diamond, quantum sensing using cascade multi photons, and a laser-based radioactive isotope analysis. © 2021 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Magnetic resonance imaging; Medical applications; Molecular imaging; Particle beams; Photons; Positron emission tomography; Quantum computers; Quantum entanglement; Single photon emission computed tomography; Biomedical applications; Biomedical imaging; Functional information; Imaging modality; Morphological information; Quanta computers; Quantum sensors; Quantum technologies; Single photon emission CT; Spatial resolution; Nuclear medicine

Title: Room temperature magnetic field learning with optically readout single NV-centers
Source title: 2019 Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe and European Quantum Electronics Conference, CLEO/Europe-EQEC 2019
Affiliations: Quantum Engineering Technology Labs, University of Bristol, Bristol, BS8 1FD, United Kingdom; Institute of Quantum Optics, Ulm University, Ulm, 89081, Germany; Quantum Architectures and Computation Group, Microsoft Research, Redmond, 98052, WA, United States

Abstract: We propose and test a Magnetic Field Learning (MFL) protocol for high-resolution, high dynamic range and high-sensitivity magnetometry with a single NV-center electron spin. Our approach leverages recent proposals that analyze the benefits of adopting classical machine learning to post-process quantum data in quantum sensing protocols [1]. MFL was tested at room-temperature using a setup detecting state-dependent fluorescence via confocal microscopy, and a microwave controlled NV defect in bulk diamond as a sensor [2]. This setup senses the intensity of a magnetic field B in the proximity of the quantum sensor via Ramsey interferometry [3]. In our protocol, the Ramsey precession time τ is adaptively chosen at each step via an efficient particle guess heuristic [1]. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: van Erp T.; Gladysz B.
Author full names: van Erp, Tim (57215521246); Gladysz, Bartlomiej (56585911900)
Title: Quantum Technologies in Manufacturing Systems: Perspectives for Application and Sustainable Development
Affiliations: University of Southern Denmark, Department of Technology and Innovation, Campusvej 55, Odense, 5230, Denmark; Warsaw University of Technology, Institute of Production Systems Organization, ul. Narbutta 86, ST120, Warszawa, 02-524, Poland
Authors with affiliations: van Erp T., University of Southern Denmark, Department of Technology and Innovation, Campusvej 55, Odense, 5230, Denmark; Gladysz B., Warsaw University of Technology, Institute of Production Systems Organization, ul. Narbutta 86, ST120, Warszawa, 02-524, Poland
Abstract: In the medium- and long-term future, quantum technologies will become a megatrend shaping global industrial value creation. Quantum technologies will open novel pathways for manufacturing systems innovations, while also providing new opportunities for Sustainable Development. Manufacturing companies must already strive for a better understanding of quantum technologies and their potential applications if they are to maintain and improve their competitive advantage in the future. An overview of the theoretical background and state-of-the-art for quantum technologies and manufacturing systems is presented. Fields of application for quantum technologies are explored in the context of relevant manufacturing systems domains. Potential applications are proposed based on an analysis and synthesis of relevant literature, industrial case studies, as well as the authors' ideations. A case is laid out for how quantum technologies can potentially facilitate industrial symbiosis within limited global ecological boundaries. In other words, the case study describes how Sustainable Development can be potentially facilitated using quantum computing and quantum AI. © 2022 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: innovation; manufacturing systems; Quantum technologies; sustainability; sustainable development

Authors: Anders J.; Pfau T.; Wrachtrup J.; Plenio M.B.; Jelezko F.; Lips K.
Title: Towards IC-based quantum sensing-recent achievements and future research trends
Affiliations: University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany; University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany; Helmholtz Zentrum Berlin for Materialien und Energie, Berlin Joint EPR Lab, Berlin, Germany; IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Anders J., University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany, IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany; Pfau T., University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany, IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany; Wrachtrup J., University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany, IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany; Plenio M.B., University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany, IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany; Jelezko F., University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany, IQST, Centre for Integrated Quantum Science and Technology, Germany; Lips K., Helmholtz Zentrum Berlin for Materialien und Energie, Berlin Joint EPR Lab, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: This paper describes some of the recent trends in the use of integrated circuit (IC) technology for the design of smart quantum sensors. To this end, after a brief introduction into the topic of quantum sensing including its intrinsic advantages and associated challenges, a number of emerging applications including the fields of IC-based inductive electron and nuclear spin detection as well as Rydberg gas sensing and NV center based sensing are used to highlight the great potential of the IC-based quantum sensing approach. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Chen J.M.; Black T.A.; Price D.T.; Carter R.E.
Title: Model for calculating photosynthetic photon flux densities in forest openings on slopes
Affiliations: Global Monitoring Section, Canada Centre for Remote Sensing, 588 Booth Street (4th Floor), Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y7, Canada.
Authors with affiliations: Chen J.M., Global Monitoring Section, Canada Centre for Remote Sensing, 588 Booth Street (4th Floor), Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y7, Canada.; Black T.A., Global Monitoring Section, Canada Centre for Remote Sensing, 588 Booth Street (4th Floor), Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y7, Canada.; Price D.T., Global Monitoring Section, Canada Centre for Remote Sensing, 588 Booth Street (4th Floor), Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y7, Canada.; Carter R.E., Global Monitoring Section, Canada Centre for Remote Sensing, 588 Booth Street (4th Floor), Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y7, Canada.
Abstract: The PPFD is separated into direct and diffuse components. The direct component is calculated according to the opening and radiation geometries, and pathlength of the solar beam through the forest canopy. The diffuse component is obtained from the sky, tree, and landscape view factors. In this model, the distribution of foliage area with height and the effect of foliage clumping on both direct and diffuse radiation transmission are considered. The model has been verified using measurements from six quantum sensors (LI-COR Inc.) located at different positions in a small clear-cut (0.37 ha) in a 90-year-old western hemlock-Douglas fir forest. -from Authors
Index Keywords: clear cutting; forest; model; photosynthetic photon flux; slope

Authors: Salmanogli A.; Gokcen D.
Author full names: Salmanogli, Ahmad (55666686400); Gokcen, Dincer (35179444500)
Title: Design of quantum sensor to duplicate European Robins navigational system
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey; Faculty of Engineering, Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Çankaya University, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Salmanogli A., Faculty of Engineering, Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey, Faculty of Engineering, Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Çankaya University, Ankara, Turkey; Gokcen D., Faculty of Engineering, Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: In this article, we design a quantum device to duplicate the European Robins procedure to precisely determine the migratory route. In the mentioned procedure, the important issue is the geomagnetic field effect on the magnetic momentum of the created radical pairs (triplet-singlet states) dancing with a special frequency. To duplicate the procedure, a quantum sensor consisting of two coincident tripartite systems is designed. Each tripartite system is independently excited with the entangled photons (signal and idler). The interesting point is that by manipulation of the system in the right condition, the microwave cavities modes separately affected by the entangled photons can be entangled. The entangled microwave photons play the same role as the triplet-singlet states present in the bird's navigational system. The key point in the design of the quantum sensor is that the entanglement between microwave photons can be strongly affected by the external magnetic field. In fact, this is the criterion employed by the quantum sensor to sense the magnetic field intensity and the direction. To analyze the system, the canonical quantization (or microscopic) method is used to determine the sensor's Hamiltonian, and also the system dynamics equations of motions are analytically derived using Heisenberg-Langevin equations. © 2021 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Entanglement; Quantum sensor; Quantum theory; Radical pair; Robin; Simulation

Authors: Luoheng Han; Rundquist D.C.
Author full names: Luoheng Han (7409555925); Rundquist, D.C. (7007038686)
Title: The response of both surface reflectance and the underwater light field to various levels of suspended sediments: preliminary results
Abstract: The purpose of the research was to investigate the relationships between and among surface spectral reflectance, the underwater light field, and suspended sediment concentrations (SSC). Both spectroradiometer and quantum-sensor data were collected over and in an 8543 litre vinyl pool, under natural sunlight. Twenty levels of SSCs ranging from 50 to 1000 mg/l were put into solution. Both downwelling and up-welling irradiances below the water surface decreased with increasing SSC, even though atmospheric downwelling increased. A relationship for PAR (Photosynthetically Active Radiation) transmittance, reflectance, and absorption with varying levels of SSC was illustrated. -from Authors

Authors: Turlington M.W.; Sattler L.E.; Pacella D.J.; Gamble J.; Toy M.
Author full names: Turlington, Matthew W. (58244309800); Sattler, Lee E. (58243337500); Pacella, Dante J. (36537831800); Gamble, Jerry (58243662100); Toy, Mehmet (57193638600)
Title: Quantum Computing and Its Impact
Source title: Future Networks, Services and Management: Underlay and Overlay, Edge, Applications, Slicing, Cloud, Space, AI/ML, and Quantum Computing
Affiliations: Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turlington M.W., Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States; Sattler L.E., Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States; Pacella D.J., Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States; Gamble J., Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States; Toy M., Verizon Communications, Inc., Basking Ridge, NJ, United States
Abstract: Quantum technology is a rapidly advancing field which will revolutionize computing and communications networking. The use of quantum technology exploits the characteristics of quantum physics. In the quantum physics realm, subatomic particles don’t follow the same set of rules as the objects we can see and touch. These differences allow new paradigms to be developed for computing and communications. Quantum computers can be used to solve previously unsolvable problems on a much larger scale. The Quantum Internet can exchange large amounts of data using quantum physics properties thereby reducing traffic on traditional communication networks. This section will detail some of the unique aspects of quantum technology. © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2021.
Author Keywords: Communications; Computing; Entanglement; Internet; Key distribution; Physics; Quantum; Qubit; Repeaters; Superdense; Superposition; Teleportation

Authors: Howard T.L.
Author full names: Howard, Timothy L. (7202242335)
Title: Aspects of quantum sensing for aerospace systems
Affiliations: University of New Mexico, Department of Physics and Astronomy, P.O. Box 91536, Albuquerque, 87199, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howard T.L., University of New Mexico, Department of Physics and Astronomy, P.O. Box 91536, Albuquerque, 87199, NM, United States
Abstract: Current technology trends indicate that quantum computers are on the threshold of broad adoption and usability across many industries. At present a number of quantum computers have been realized in hardware, typically with only a few qubits and with performance limitations including short coherence times, difficult coupling to input/output processing, and strong susceptibility to noise in the ambient environment. However, the separate but closely related field of quantum sensing shows much more near-term promise in respect of its applicability to broad classes of systems and missions, including many types of aerospace systems, sensors, and the processing and evaluation of their data. This paper reviews the basic methodology and types of quantum sensing, some history of related measurements and proof-of-concept experiments, and assesses the potential applicability of quantum sensing techniques to future aerospace sensors and systems. Performance metrics using published models and demonstration experiments show distinct performance advantages in several cases and are used to compare near-term quantum sensing to more conventional systems. In addition, the application of quantum communication to networked systems is discussed, along with the potential for novel data fusion techniques using quantum-inspired protocols and methods. © 2020, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gilbert G.; Hamrick M.; Weinstein Y.S.; Pappas S.P.; Donadio A.
Title: Quantum sensor miniaturization
Affiliations: MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilbert G., MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Hamrick M., MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Weinstein Y.S., MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Pappas S.P., MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States; Donadio A., MITRE Quantum Information Science Group, MITRE, Eatontown, NJ 07724, United States
Abstract: The classical bound on image resolution defined by the Rayleigh limit can be beaten by exploiting the properties of quantum mechanical entanglement. If entangled photons are used as signal states, the best possible resolution is instead given by the Heisenberg limit, an improvement proportional to the number of entangled photons in the signal. In this letter, we present a novel application of entanglement by showing that the resolution obtained by an imaging system utilizing separable photons can be achieved by an imaging system making use of entangled photons, but with the advantage of a smaller aperture, thus resulting in a smaller and lighter system. This can be especially valuable in satellite imaging where weight and size play a vital role. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Entanglement; N00N states; Quantum interferometry; Rayleigh limit
Index Keywords: Image resolution; Imaging systems; Optical sensors; Photons; Satellite imagery; Entangled photons; Heisenberg limit; Quantum interferometry; Quantum sensor; Quantum theory

Authors: Kasai H.; Takeuchi Y.; Hakoshima H.; Matsuzaki Y.; Tokura Y.
Author full names: Kasai, Hiroto (57224540537); Takeuchi, Yuki (57189215779); Hakoshima, Hideaki (57205564528); Matsuzaki, Yuichiro (35590439500); Tokura, Yasuhiro (55486104400)
Title: Anonymous Quantum Sensing
Source title: Journal of the Physical Society of Japan
Affiliations: Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8571, Japan; Research Center for Emerging Computing Technologies, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Central 2, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8568, Japan; NTT Communication Science Laboratories, NTT Corporation, Kanagawa, Atsugi, 243-0198, Japan; Center for Quantum Information and Quantum Biology, Osaka University, Osaka, Toyonaka, 560-0043, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kasai H., Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8571, Japan, Research Center for Emerging Computing Technologies, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Central 2, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8568, Japan; Takeuchi Y., NTT Communication Science Laboratories, NTT Corporation, Kanagawa, Atsugi, 243-0198, Japan; Hakoshima H., Research Center for Emerging Computing Technologies, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Central 2, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8568, Japan, Center for Quantum Information and Quantum Biology, Osaka University, Osaka, Toyonaka, 560-0043, Japan; Matsuzaki Y., Research Center for Emerging Computing Technologies, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Central 2, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8568, Japan; Tokura Y., Graduate School of Pure and Applied Sciences, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki, Tsukuba, 305-8571, Japan
Abstract: A lot of attention has been paid to a quantum-sensing network for detecting magnetic fields in different positions. Recently, cryptographic quantum metrology was investigated where the information of the magnetic fields is transmitted in a secure way. However, sometimes, the positions where non-zero magnetic fields are generated could carry important information. Here, we propose an anonymous quantum sensor where an information of positions having non-zero magnetic fields is hidden after measuring magnetic fields with a quantum-sensing network. Suppose that participants are located in different positions and they have quantum sensors. After the quantum sensors are entangled, the participants implement quantum sensing that provides a phase information if non-zero magnetic fields exist, and POVM measurement is performed on quantum sensors. Importantly, even if the outcomes of the POVM measurement is stolen by an eavesdropper, information of the positions with non-zero magnetic fields is still unknown for the eavesdropper in our protocol. Here, tracelessness is guaranteed, and so our protocol is considered as anonymous. In addition, we evaluate the sensitivity of our proposed quantum sensors by using Fisher information when there are at most two positions having non-zero magnetic fields. We show that the sensitivity is finite unless these two (non-zero) magnetic fields have exactly the same amplitude. Our results pave the way for new applications of quantum-sensing network. © 2022 The Physical Society of Japan

Authors: Morishita H.; Morioka N.; Nishikawa T.; Yao H.; Onoda S.; Abe H.; Ohshima T.; Mizuochi N.
Author full names: Morishita, Hiroki (35795753400); Morioka, Naoya (34870329700); Nishikawa, Tetsuri (57991687900); Yao, Hajime (58165620200); Onoda, Shinobu (7005380317); Abe, Hiroshi (57205357122); Ohshima, Takeshi (7201525435); Mizuochi, Norikazu (55880840600)
Title: Spin-Dependent Photocarrier Generation Dynamics in Electrically Detected Nitrogen-Vacancy-Based Quantum Sensor
Source title: 2023 IEEE International Magnetic Conference - Short Papers, INTERMAG Short Papers 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Center for Science and Innovation in Spintronics, Miyagi, Japan; Tohoku University, WPI Advanced Institute for Materials Research, Miyagi, Japan; Kyoto University, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan; Kyoto University, Center for Spintronics Research Network, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan; National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Gunma, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morishita H., Tohoku University, Center for Science and Innovation in Spintronics, Miyagi, Japan, Tohoku University, WPI Advanced Institute for Materials Research, Miyagi, Japan; Morioka N., Kyoto University, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan, Kyoto University, Center for Spintronics Research Network, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan; Nishikawa T., Kyoto University, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan; Yao H., Kyoto University, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan; Onoda S., National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Gunma, Japan; Abe H., National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Gunma, Japan; Ohshima T., National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Gunma, Japan; Mizuochi N., Kyoto University, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan, Kyoto University, Center for Spintronics Research Network, Institute for Chemical Research, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Electrical detection of a nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center in diamond is advantageous for developing and integrating quantum information processing devices and quantum sensors. However, the mechanism for the electrical detection of NV spins is not fully understood. In this study, we observe positive contrast in photoelectrically detected magnetic resonance (PDMR) despite the usually observed negative PDMR contrast. To discuss the sign of the PDMR contrast, we numerically analyze the dynamics of photocarrier generation by NV centers using a seven-level rate model. It is found that the sign of the PDMR contrast depends on the difference in the photocurrent generated from the excited states and the metastable state of NV centers. Furthermore, we demonstrate alternating-current (AC) magnetic field sensing using spin coherence with the PDMR technique using a phase-cycling-based noise-canceling technique to suppress the noise from a fluctuating magnetic environment. We obtained the sensitivity of AC magnetic-field of ∼29nT/√Hz with the PDMR technique.  © 2023 IEEE.
